goals.1: Recognize that all matter is made of atoms.
goals.2: Recognize that different types of atoms are called elements.
goals.3: Recognize that all elements are organized on the periodic table.
goals.4: Identify metals, non-metals and semi-metals on the periodic table and describe properties of metals that make them different from non-metals.
goals.5: Identify the names of the elements of the first two rows of the periodic table and attach the name to pictures.
goals.6: Identify solids, liquids and gases on the periodic table.
goals.7: Sketch particle pictures for solids, liquids and gases.
goals.8: Observe animations and describe the motion as translational, rotational or vibrational.
goals.9: Observe animations and link the motions to the physical state of matter (solid, liquid, gas).
goals.10: Predict how temperature changes the speed of particles.
goals.12: Perform calculations with numbers written in scientific notation.
goals.13: Estimate orders of magnitude based on scientific notation.
goals.14: Convert among metric prefixes without being given the conversion factor.
goals.15: Convert between any given set of units, if given the conversion factors, using proportions or dimensional analysis.

goals.1: Draw a planetary picture of the atom and identify the component particles of an atom.
goals.2: Use isotope notation to obtain the number of protons, neutrons and electrons for any atom or ion.
goals.3: Write and interpret the isotopic representation of an element.
goals.4: Use the periodic table to obtain the number of protons for a given atom or atom symbol, or determine the number of protons given an atom name or symbol.
goals.5: Articulate the principle that an atom’s identity is determined by the number of protons.
goals.6: Calculate the average mass number from the periodic table for any element based on isotope abundance and formula mass.
goals.7: Identify the s, p, d and f shapes of the atomic orbitals.
goals.8: Break the periodic table into four distinct sections that refer to the orbital (s, p, d, f) of the valence electrons.
goals.9: Write electronic configurations for any atom and its ions using the periodic table (both long-hand and noble-gas configurations).
goals.10: Identify ionic charges based on the position of an element on the periodic table for atoms in Groups 1, 2, 15, 16 and 17.
goals.11: Determine the magnetism (paramagnetic or diamagnetic) of any atom or ion based on its electron configuration.

goals.1: Recognize that all bonding occurs due to electrostatic interactions between electrons and the nucleus.
goals.2: Recognize that the name of the electrostatic interaction is Coulomb’s law and that the strength of attraction between charged particles increases as the particles get closer.
goals.3: Recognize that like charges repel and opposite charges attract, so atomic nuclei without electrons would repel and electrons are needed to mediate nuclear repulsions.
goals.4: Identify ionically bonded compounds by the positions of the atoms on the periodic table.
goals.5: Balance ionic charges to generate chemical formulas for ionic compounds.
goals.6: Identify binary compounds from their chemical formula and determine whether the compound is ionic or covalent.
goals.7: Name binary ionic and binary covalent compounds from the chemical formula.
goals.8: Write the chemical formula from the chemical name of a binary ionic or binary covalent compound.
goals.9: Recognize, recall and name all polyatomic ions in the table of polyatomic ions, knowing the formula and charge for each ion.
goals.10: Construct and name ionic compounds that contain polyatomic ions.
goals.11: Identify ionic charges based on the position of an element on the periodic table for any atom.
goals.12: Write electronic configurations for any ion using the periodic table.
goals.13: Identify the number of atoms of each atom type in a given chemical formula.

goals.1: Identify molecules with covalent bonds by looking at the position of the atoms on the periodic table and comparing relative electronegativities.
goals.2: Use electronegativity to predict bond polarity.
goals.3: Predict the number of valence electrons for any atom or ion based on its position on the periodic table.
goals.4: Sketch electronic distribution based on Lewis structure and bond polarity.
goals.5: Assess the validity of a given Lewis structure.
goals.6: Draw Lewis structures for simple covalently bonded molecules using atoms from the first and second rows of the periodic table.
goals.7: Use Lewis structures to predict trends in bond length and bond strength.

goals.1: Articulate the principle of conservation of matter and how balancing equations relates to that principle.
goals.2: Balance the number of atoms in a chemical reaction on the reactant and product side given the chemical equation.
goals.3: Balance the number of atoms in a chemical reaction on the reactant and product side given a word equation.
goals.4: Use the balanced chemical equation to compute the numbers of atoms or molecules produced or consumed in a chemical reaction.

goals.1: Recognize the difference between potential and kinetic energy and know examples of potential energy, namely gravitational and electrostatic.
goals.2: Write a clear statement defining chemical potential energy and link endothermic and exothermic reactions to the energy of reactants and products in a chemical reaction.
goals.3: Identify endothermic or exothermic reactions from the position of heat in a chemical reaction or from the signs of ΔE and/or ΔH.
goals.4: Identify endothermic or exothermic reactions from reaction coordinate diagrams.
goals.5: Recognize that all combustion reactions are exothermic.
goals.6: Link changes in temperature of the surroundings to changes in energy of a system for endothermic and exothermic reactions.
goals.7: State whether energy is released or required (absorbed) when a bond breaks or is formed.
goals.8: Link endothermicity or exothermicity to the net change in bonds broken and formed.
goals.9: Use a table of bond energies to compute the total energy change for a chemical reaction and to predict the thermicity (endo or exo) of a reaction.

goals.1: Use Coulomb’s law to describe the source of potential energy in atoms (electrostatic potential energy) and the energy of motion of the electrons.
goals.2: Note that energy of the atom typically means the electrostatic potential energy and the kinetic energy of the electrons.
goals.3: Recall the definitions of atomic size, electronegativity, ionization energy and electron affinity.
goals.4: Recognize the periodic trends for these properties based on the periodic table for elements and their ions.
goals.5: Rationalize the periodic properties of elements and ions.
goals.6: Recall and rationalize the exceptions to the ionization energy trend.
goals.7: Write electron configurations for a series of isoelectronic ions.
goals.8: Predict the relative sizes of isoelectronic ions.
goals.9: Interpret graphs of periodic properties as a function of atomic number.

goals.1: Use (without memorizing) the Rydberg equation to calculate energy levels.
goals.2: Use the Rydberg equation to calculate energy differences for specific transitions or calculate specific transitions from energy differences.
goals.3: Use the relationship between wavelength and frequency to compute wavelength from frequency and vice versa for light.
goals.4: Relate the color of light to its frequency or wavelength.
goals.5: Identify the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum and demonstrate that visible light is a small fraction of the EM spectrum.
goals.6: Use the Planck equation to relate the energy of a photon to its frequency or wavelength.
goals.7: Identify the low-energy vs high-energy ends of the EM spectrum and relate this to wavelengths and frequency.
goals.8: Recognize how the electromagnetic spectrum is used to probe atomic structure.
goals.9: Use an atomic spectrum to compute possible energy-level transitions.
goals.10: Use an atomic spectrum to compute the nuclear charge.
goals.11: Relate energy level differences of an atom to the wavelength of the corresponding photon.
goals.12: Use the Rydberg equation to compute a line spectrum.

goals.1: Describe the failure of the classical model to explain the hydrogen atom’s stability.
goals.2: Describe the duality of nature, including what defines a particle (mass and position) and what defines a wave (diffraction and interference).
goals.3: Calculate the mass of a photon and recognize the Compton effect as an experiment suggesting photons have mass and are therefore particles.
goals.4: Use the de Broglie equation to calculate wavelengths of particles and realize that particles can act as waves.
goals.5: Be familiar with the double-slit experiment and how it is used to demonstrate wave behavior.
goals.6: Recognize that the s, p, d and f orbitals are the wavefunctions of electrons and represent electron density and positional probability.
goals.7: Relate the quantum number l to the orbital subshell notation (s, p, d, f).
goals.8: Recognize and determine the allowed quantum numbers n, l and ml.
goals.9: Identify the s, p, d and f blocks on the periodic table and use that to predict some quantum numbers.
goals.10: Interpret radial distributions of electrons and relate radial nodes and radial pictures to three-dimensional orbital shapes.
goals.11: Identify the correct number of angular nodes for s, p and d orbitals.
goals.12: Recognize the resulting electron density from superimposed orbitals.
goals.13: Relate radial distribution curves to energy-level diagrams.

goals.1: Recognize that bond formation results in a lowering of energy.
goals.2: Predict if a bond is polar using a table of electronegativities.
goals.3: Predict whether a molecule with a given shape has a dipole moment based on adding (pictorially) individual bond dipole moments or symmetry.
goals.4: Given a picture, determine whether a molecule has a dipole moment, or knowing the dipole moment, predict how the electrostatic potential might look.
goals.5: Draw resonance structures for appropriate molecules.
goals.6: Recognize that bonding in resonance structures produces a non-integer bond order.
goals.7: Calculate formal charges for each atom from a Lewis structure.
goals.8: Evaluate resonance structures and determine the hybrid structure.
goals.9: Relate bond length, bond strength and bond order to particular resonance structures.
goals.10: Draw Lewis structures for molecules that are exceptions to the octet rule.
goals.11: Predict and name the electron geometries and corresponding bond angles for covalent molecules using VSEPR.
goals.12: Predict molecular shapes from a name and/or chemical formula using Lewis structures and VSEPR rules.

goals.1: Recognize sp, sp2, sp3, dsp3 and d2sp3 hybridization.
goals.2: State the hybridization of carbon’s atomic orbitals when given a valid Lewis structure.
goals.3: Recognize sigma and pi bonds and relate those to bond order.
goals.4: Sketch sigma and pi bonds from the overlap of hybrid orbitals.
goals.5: Explain why there is rotation around a single bond but not around multiple bonds.

goals.1: Draw the resulting bonding and antibonding orbitals when two s orbitals overlap, two p orbitals overlap head-on, or two p orbitals overlap sideways.
goals.2: Distinguish among sigma (σ), pi (π), σ* and π* (bonding and antibonding) orbitals in molecular orbital theory.
goals.3: Identify nodes in a molecular orbital.
goals.4: Given an energy diagram, predict observable properties such as bond order, magnetism, bond length and electron density.

goals.1: Recall and apply the basic rules of scientific notation, rounding, metric units and dimensional analysis.
goals.2: Rearrange a basic algebraic expression to isolate any variable in the expression (i.e. mass = moles × molar mass).
goals.3: Revisit balancing a chemical equation and use the coefficients to predict the number of atoms or molecules produced or used in a chemical reaction.
goals.4: Articulate that the atomic mass in the periodic table is the number of grams in a mole of the element, or equivalently, the number of grams in an Avogadro's number of atoms.
goals.6: Use the periodic table to determine the mass (in grams) of a given mole of different substances.
goals.7: Interpret the chemical formula to compute the molar mass.
goals.8: Convert between moles and masses for an arbitrary amount of matter.
goals.9: Convert between numbers of particles, moles and grams.
goals.10: Scale up the coefficients to realize that they can refer to the number of atoms and molecules or to the number of moles.
goals.11: Balance chemical equations and recognize that coefficients can represent mole numbers.

goals.1: Identify the limiting and excess reagents in a chemical reaction based on given amounts of reactants.
goals.2: Use the chemical equation to compute the maximum amount (theoretical yield) of products produced.
goals.3: Use the chemical equation to compute the amount of reactants needed to produce a 100% yield.
goals.4: Use the chemical equation to predict the masses of all components after a reaction has run to 100% completion, including amount of reactant reacted, amount of reactant unreacted (excess), and amount of product produced.
goals.5: Recognize the actual yield in a chemical reaction based on the wording of a problem.
goals.6: Compute percent yields for any chemical reaction from actual yields and theoretical yields.
goals.7: Incorporate limiting reagent calculations into stoichiometric calculations starting with given amounts of reactants or given amounts of products.
goals.8: For any given set of conditions, compute the amounts of reactants and products in the reaction vessel (including mole, mass, percent yield and/or number of particles).

goals.1: Compute percent composition for any element based on the chemical formula of a compound.
goals.2: Obtain the empirical formula from mass measurements, percent composition and chemical reactions.
goals.3: Obtain molecular formulas from empirical formulas and molecular weight data.
goals.4: Determine empirical and molecular formulas from combustion reactions.

goals.1: Draw particle diagrams that distinguish gas and liquid phases and describe the motion in each phase.
goals.2: Identify the six phase transitions: evaporation, condensation, freezing, melting, sublimation and deposition.
goals.3: Identify the different phases and phase transitions on a heating curve and phase diagram.
goals.4: Recognize the phase transitions that require the most energy.
goals.5: Interpret a phase diagram and identify the normal boiling point, normal freezing point, triple point and the vapor pressure at different temperatures.
goals.6: Recognize that heat and temperature are different concepts; temperature is a measure of kinetic energy of the particles and heat is a transfer of energy from one body to another.
goals.7: Define vapor pressure and describe its trends as a function of temperature.
goals.8: Draw a particle diagram representing vapor pressure.
goals.9: Define the normal boiling point in terms of vapor pressure.
goals.10: Describe the difference between intermolecular forces and intramolecular forces.
goals.11: Describe the three main intermolecular forces (London dispersion, dipole–dipole and hydrogen bonding) and rank their relative strengths.
goals.12: Recognize and predict the intermolecular forces present in a substance when given its name or chemical structure.

goals.1: List the ideal gas postulates and relate them to the motion of gas molecules.
goals.2: Identify the four variables used to characterize a gas quantitatively (P, T, V and n).
goals.3: Describe pressure as an average force per area.
goals.4: Recognize when the average force increases due to changes in momentum or collision frequency.
goals.5: Realize that the pressure of a gas is proportional to the mole number of the gas (at constant P, T, V), so gas pressure can be used in place of mole in stoichiometry calculations.
goals.6: Assign proper units to each variable: P in atm, n in moles, T in Kelvin and V in liters, and use R = 0.0821 L·atm/(mol·K).
goals.7: Convert among units of volume (mL, L, cm³), pressure (torr, atm, kPa) and temperature (°C and K).
goals.8: Write the ideal gas law and use algebra to rearrange PV = nRT to isolate each variable.
goals.9: Identify problems as single-state problems and set up the single-state equation with one unknown.
goals.10: Identify problems as two-state problems and determine which variables are changing and which are constant.
goals.11: Modify the single-state equation to explicitly solve for density, mass or molar mass.
goals.12: Solve double-state problems for an unknown and for relative changes in volume and pressure.
goals.13: Relate the speeds of particles to their kinetic energy and use a graph to show that different particles have different energies at one temperature.
goals.14: Recall and write down the relationships between PV and kinetic energy and between T and kinetic energy.
goals.15: Use the PV and kinetic energy equations to relate speed and mass (and molar mass) to temperature.
goals.16: Predict relative average speeds and relative diffusion rates of gaseous particles.
goals.17: Predict relative speeds of effusion and diffusion.

goals.1: Draw particle diagrams for dissolving an ionic solid in water or for dissolving a polar covalent compound in water.
goals.2: Identify the solute and the solvent in a solution.
goals.3: Use the molarity formula to compute mass, moles, volume or molarity.
goals.4: Use the dilution formula to compute molarity and volume after dilution.
goals.5: Identify and name the three types of reactions: combustion, synthesis/decomposition and precipitation/dissolution.
goals.6: Predict products of combustion reactions from known oxides.
goals.7: Predict products of synthesis and decomposition reactions.
goals.8: Predict products of precipitation reactions using solubility rules.
goals.9: Write molecular and net ionic equations for precipitation and dissolution reactions.
goals.10: Demonstrate knowledge of nomenclature rules, reaction types and predicting products by performing stoichiometric calculations for reactions containing solids, liquids, gases or solutions.
